uRPENl8xNREoJsAMgniVhA.text: I've been going to this place for dim sum on and off for over 10 years. By far give the best variety of dim sum in the valley and give it to you straight. I'm originally from the Bay Area and went to china town there for dim sum and some of the dishes at C-Fu are just as good. I'd recommend this place to anyone looking for dim sum in the valley.

laD6YJAusez_eOiuTnCYDw.text: The dim sum appetizer platter was good, the orange chicken was ok. My husband couldn't chew the beef in the hot pot and had to spit it out. All of the beef in the pot was super gristly with chunks of what looked like just tendon or cartilage. We googled it and that's how its supposed to be, it just wasn't to our liking, so not their fault. When they saw we didn't eat it they took it off our bill.

H6TNZnKvEWgr1_Ome6mTUQ.text: I go here every so often with a large group for dim sum, though I prefer Phoenix Palace across the street. My husband loves their bbq pork and I love their steamed and baked bbq pork buns. A lot of other food there can be greasy but tasty and satisfying. The room is huge and it does fill up around noon on Sundays (best time to go), but we've never had to wait long.

VTJNvgbwKKfewKV-R66xdA.text: Some say that C-Fu has the best Chinese food in the Phoenix area, I disagree. I'd say that C-Fu is definitely above average, but not the best.   It's definitely worth a trip, especially during lunch when they serve dim sum.  C-Fu  not only has the standard menu items such as Sweet and Sour Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and Chow Mein, but they also have some unique items such as Shark Fin Soup, several duck and ostrich dishes, and sea cucumber dishes.  Above average taste coupled with good dim sum gives C-Fu an above average rating of four stars.

Op_U58ZYedButQz_2KJGUA.text: Avoid on weekdays if you want Dim Sum!  The last two times I went there I left after sitting at a table for 20 minutes with no food. Sometimes a cart would go by - a different table.    No amount of hand waving or imploring looks would do any good.  You couldn't drag me in there kicking and screaming on a weekday again.

-iBsfRn5dw_2w3vJo8kfPw.text: If you are in the area and craving dim sum, do yourself a favor and go to phoenix across the street. The dim sum was luke warm and the restaurants is not clean- sticky plates, dirty carts, and saw a waitress drop her rag only to put it back on her cart. I will not be returning....ever!

DeHmtIDQGBgrSi7nW3-Bog.text: Worst dimsum I have ever eating.  Receptionist has horrible attitude.  The guy I think is the owner.  We had 16 people and they refused to put 2 tables together.

gK72uhH8OR_7Kc7l59cLfg.text: I am long time fan! Reasonable prices and good food.

_ajV5Etxg8sP8q0iyJplNg.text: This is by far the best Dim Sum on the east side.  The food is always good and really pretty consistent.    The pork with rice noodles is my favorite and my daughter loves the shrimp dumplings.    When I was there last weekend they had some weird Karoke thing--- but other than that is always a good place to chat and enjoy a morning treat.

PwR_ZBfM4bCyHYOttVn-Jw.text: Went here for dim sum and was very pleased with the selection and the food was very tasty.  Price was very good. We ate a lot and the bill was very reasonable. I have had dim sum at Great Wall and Mekong Palace and in my opinion C-fu is better.

2cJBGJYhgy_bZEuQ0EYgOA.text: I've only been here for dim sum so I can't rate their other food items, but I give their dim sum 5 stars. Their service is fast, friendly, and they have a large selection of exactly what you'd expect from a good dim sum place. My belly sure was satisfied!! We will definitely be back. :)

7-52t55vgwDFDfq2l4Bpzg.text: The Dim Sum here isn't bad and it is certainly better than anything in Tucson. It can't be compared to  San Francisco Dim Sum but for AZ, it's just fine. I DO like their beef rice rolls and chow mien noodles. Though I always get either Chinese broccoli or baby bok choy, I always eat it plain since the sauce that comes with is a little too salty. It is always worth getting the tea. The service is friendly, it's not expensive, and the experience here is always pleasant.

iu7SdcG-xKgXrirWD6FW-g.text: Quite possibly the best restaurant in the greater Phoenix area.  Almost everything is recommended from daily dim sum breakfasts, to Sesame chicken afternoon lunches, to Chilean Seabass dinner, to nightclub and beer on weekends.  Highly recommended.

ZimdCe2xCAOOZjt1aQAMvg.text: SEVERAL years ago, this was the place to grab dim sum.  But much better have popped up and the crowds moved on, and this fell to the wayside.  You can tell easily by the lack of (Asian) customers.  On a whim, tried it again.  Meh.  Egg tarts were the best part, but there is so much better dim sum not much farther away.

BvgJB5WeGW_ODxUOszRzLQ.text: I went back after a bit of time and after invites from the Manager after my last visit.  I decided to go back after the manager talked to me after a bit.  I decided to go for it.  I went back for the pork wonton soup.  I added a bit of soy sauce and it was good.  It wasn't the best I ever had but it was good.  Also the staff was HUGE in making up for my last visit.  That is a plus.    10 minutes and  the soup was ready and waiting.  It was hot and good.  I added the soy sauce to add a bit of salty which I like.  It was good.  The pork was fattier than I've had elsewhere but it was good otherwise.  The food was decent and the staff was cool.    Now, I have not tried the in house dim sum.  As it was I have to give props for a great manager.  The duck soup is normally served with bones, according to the manager.  Not my thing but I was glad he explained it.  Tradition can be big even if it is not to my tastes.  I guess that is a good heads up to potential customers.    It was fair goods and very nice service.  If it was less fatty, they would have gotten a 4 but they get a 4 for service and a 2 for chow this time around.  I am not shy about my review.  I give what I get.  If they impress me better next time, I will post so.    However as it was, fair food and great service.  3 out of 5 for now.  Thanks to the staff for being huge and I got fed and was fairly pleased with the chow.  Not wowed but pleased.

YasfPvFjHmxXDYzjnZPDGw.text: I've been meeting with friends here for dim sum for the past few years and also had dinner here a few weeks ago. The food is consistently quite good, affordable, and fresh. The service is generally quite good as well.  My bride and I held our wedding reception here this past weekend in the small private room at the back of the dining room. The service and food were great and our guests enjoyed the dim sum adventure, a first for many of them. Fun and affordable!  The fun part is we'll be able to return to our reception restaurant with our friends anytime we like.

8_ESdq9bvDy-5_IHbPnroA.text: Much better than China King.  I did find it strange that the cart pushing ladies didn't speak a lick of Cantonese.  It's a decent place for dim sum, but the chicken shui mai is something I could do without.  I don't know why they couldn't have pork like everyone else.  A limited tea selection, and the prices are a bit on the expensive side.  Especially when there isn't too much variety found here.  It's decent enough for lunch, just nothing that'll make this top tier.

R-LshAPY6w4HN9yB2CZc8A.text: Ordered take out dim sum, staff was rude...went home and the order was wrong....check your order before you leave, the char siu bao had too much fat, hardly any meat....not going back.

slaatobNtX68Y5MoO1A8sQ.text: Hello Arizona Foodies and Happy Holidays!  I am delighted to report I have been back to C-fu a couple of times in the last 6 months simply because compared to the rest out there in my local area this is the best choice.  We found that the food has gotten back to what it used to be, along with the selection of items and the service.  There are many of the regular dim sum items along with some interesting tid bits.  The food has been warm or better which is a far cry from the cold it was for a while there.  We went for our tradition Xmas dinner and unfortuantely they did NOT have their act together!  The owner was running around like a chicken with his head cut off.  There was noone to fill water, tea etc.... and the selections were not as quick as normal.  I come here each year for Xmas and usually the service is better....they know to expect the Xmas crowd but I am guessing they were very short handed.  I am glad I decied to give it another shot and will be returning.  My suggestion is to wait until 11:30 or so before going on a Sunday to get the best and freshest selections.  So go..... experience and enjoy!  Bon Appetite'

AZ0rrZFfit9z9RGb-AEfZw.text: Place has gone sadly down hill for 10 years. Needs a drastic clean up, especially the carpet. One sad looking fish in tank. Went with another couple. Dim sum on low  side of average for quality. selection and freshness. Fried lacked any crispness, manapua (pork buns) were doughy and lacked filling.. Only Chinese broccoli was worth eating. BBQ pork was badly dried up. Now split into a Japanese restaurant on the west and original on the east. Don't expect S.F, or NYC . Server began offering 2 for 1 at one o'lock. which we declined. Needs an overhaul & return to its'  roots. China King  is  slightly better  and Mekong Palace is much better,this is no longer even tourist grade food.

LXXBRszm-QlossQQXmkYXA.text: We've been here several times but today was the last time--arrived around 12:30PM as the place was empty. My wife ordered a cup of Wonton Soup which arrive warmish. I ordered a standard portion of the Spice Hot & Sour Soup--it arrived very hot temperature wise and was kind of bland. As I was on the fourth spoon full, our main course arrived. One order of Mongolian Beef which arrived warm to hot and one order of Orange Chicken that arrived warmish at best. Seems the whole order was done at once with the main dishes left inside the kitchen and NOT kept hot. Since the main dishes arrived, I stop consuming the soup as I figured the main dishes would get cooled off. I was wrong as they were already cooled off. Took all the leftovers home to see if they would be better heated up. Sometimes it just doesn't pay to bring this issue up to the manager. I've done this before as they act as if they don't understand. If you like cooled off hot items, this is the place for you!

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Top is Orange chicken. Bottom is the  Mongolian Beef  we ordered.

XvSK7xMmOinJwDPvezpVBA.text: The best dim sum I've ever had !  My favorite Chinese restaurant!!!! David ,Peter and the staff are amazing

yJuFIDCmhAKiatSp9sIRhw.text: I have been here before but couldn't remember if I liked it or not. We usually always go to China King but I thought we should try it again. And it's all coming back to me now, I remember and I will never forget that I will never come back.   The shumai (excuse the spelling) was terrible I think it was all leftover pieces I couldn't even chew it. I spit it out!    It was just bad. People there are friendly. Sorry I won't be back. I will remember. All the dim sum was a very poor quality. It tasted and the texture was very cheap ingredients.

LCGQvLNsxnTSIc-Tx7vATQ.text: I am so disappointed and beyond unsatisfied with both the food but especially the customer service! It was our first time for dinner and the workers look and act miserable here! They don't smile , they take a really long time to take your order and almost complete ignore you ...They only somewhat half smile when they hand you the overpriced bill!   The food is nothing's special and better at smaller restaurants that give better service -  Save your money and Time and go across the street to Phoenix Palace... At least they are faster at taking orders, cooking food, and giving you the bill

l9gG4elX3lHfHyJ8JcoFyg.text: DIM SUM REVIEW:  So my dinner here previously wasn't too bad, but the weekday dim sum I had here was horrendous. I was pretty embarrassed--brought some co-workers here for their first dim sum experience ever and I ended up apologizing for how bad the food was. They ended up ordering regular lunch entrees after trying their first couple dim sum items (I could have died of embarassment).  Siumai were cold and hard as rocks, ha gao very dry and chewy-skinned, charsiubao filling was odd-tasting, etc...we came at about 1230 so it wasn't off-peak lunch hours or anything. The selection of dim sum was dismal overall as well.   So for regular entrees, this place is ok. But if you're looking for dim sum, check out China King or Phoenix Palace just a few blocks away.

koQo96Gwg1KINoho8YwTqA.text: It is so much fun to come here and have Dim Sum for lunch. Everyone is so nice and friendly.  The food is great too!

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. The table filled up fast!
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Shrimp 4 ways!
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States

QRRzyYAvONAhZ7Ji7X1gLg.text: Ok so I read in the Phoenix paper that this place is in the top 10 Chinese restaurants in the metro area.  I don't know if it is or isn't in the top 10 but conceding for the sake of discussion that it is I'm not sure what that says about Chinese food in the Phoenix area.  Since it was our first time here we ordered simple and perhaps overly obvious choices.  We started with hot and sour soup followed up with egg rolls, crab puffs and fried shrimp.  Soup was good.  Crab puff was actually had a crab like substance in it that you could taste over the cream cheese.  The shrimp was ok, but cold.  The egg roll was ok.  The bad thing about the crab puff and egg roll was that the grease they were fried in was very old and discolored the wonton wrappers.  Main course was beef and green beans, sweet and sour pork and fried rice.  The fried rice was good.  Beef and beans were good although the beef was a bit on the chewy side.  The sweet and sour pork was sweet and sour pork...what can you say.  Again, since the sweet and sour pork was deep fried it was cooked in the same old oil mentioned above.    All in all it was ok, but they really need to change/clean their oil.

accbVSz7JGzG-I52uY5jyw.text: I took my son here for dinner tonight after trying to get into Shimugamo next-door which was full. When we saw the place was nearly completely empty we should have known better. We tried lettuce wraps, moo shoo shrimp and a mixed seafood noodle dish, everything taste exactly the same. It was just awful. After serving our entrees with the appetizer at the same time, no one ever came back to check on us. And didn't they even bother to ask if we'd liked the food when it was obvious we didn't eat much of it at all. This place used to be really good, sadly no longer.

hDNmsmv73WVoVnyiTQ3ZRA.text: I'm torn on whether to give this restaurant 3 or 4 stars. I ate here for a banquet for an association, so I didn't get any choice in the menu. I think if I had a choice in the menu I would've enjoyed the food more and given it 4 stars. So I'm really only evaluating the banquet experience.  The room is spacious, servers were friendly (although some seemed clueless and talked very loudly while the presentation was going on), the decorations on stage are terrible and cheesy, the sound system kept giving feedback while people were speaking.  As for the food, I really enjoyed the seafood dishes, the chicken dishes were just kind of meh. The stand out for the night was the sesame balls they served for dessert.  I would come back here again, as the reviews for dim sum all seem favorable. For a Phoenix-area Chinese restaurant it's pretty good, but in general for a Chinese restuarant it's just about average.

O6X4GNfDvGAyz41fmttjgQ.text: Love this place. It looks like an event location but don't let that fool ya. They have great dim sum and lunch specials. The chicken and broccoli is freaking good. The fried rice is very good not greasy.

pxVGU8ArxGY1BFw2HIbeYA.text: Went around noon on a Sunday. They were not very busy. My 6 year old grandson had orange chicken off the dim sum cart. They do not have a kids menu so this was suggested by our waiter. When a 6 year old tells you that his orange chicken is bland, something is wrong. I tasted it and he was right. My 3 year old granddaughter had the chicken fried rice. She ate a lot of it (she is picky so wouldn't try any of the other food at the table). I tasted it and it was quite good. I had the Mongolian Beef--excellent flavor, slightly spicy, and the beef was very tender. My daughter had the garlic chicken and rice. It was OK, but I noticed that she ate very little of it. Service was good. The room was nicely decorated. We had to park quite far from the door. Lunch and beverages for 2 adults and 2 children came to $53.04 before the tip. I noticed that most dishes were $9 and up.

J3r_nlzNUB7HQJcRbxeW7w.text: My favorite dimsum restaurant!  I lived in Hong Kong for 8years and know what real Chinese/dimsum restaurants are.   Although we are not Chinese, we do dimsum on Sundays. So when we moved to Phoenix from Miami, we tried different dimsum places in Phoenix area.  We picked up some local Chinese news papers from a Chinese grocery store and tried the restaurants advertised on it. (written in Chinese, so we assumed they are authentic).   We went to Phoenix Palace, Golden Buddha, Mekong Palace, China King and C-Fu and concluded C-Fu offers the best dimsum.  Our criteria; 1. Variety 2. Taste 3. Freshness 4. Service 5. Price  Phoenix Palace might be the second best. They are as good as C-Fu in variety, taste and freshness, followed by China King whose variety is not high. Golden Buddha is the last. Golden Budda is not Cantonese restaurant anyway.   Staff are all nice at C-Fu and dishes categorized as "A" and "B" are all $2.28 which seem to include most of steamed dishes except expensive ones like shark fin dumplings. We normally spend $25-30 for two including tip.  C-Fu beats all the other places for the super flaky and tasty egg tarts. This is another reason we love C-Fu.

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States

6LmFy7DtgB2D1f6SLT5vag.text: Great food and great service as always.  The best Orange chicken in town. The Egg drop soup was awesome.

UQIpQrqNx2WuH5qzJwhvuA.text: I live in the West Valley so going out to eat here is a drive but hey, it's worth it.  We usually come here for dim sum and although I've had better, this is probably as good as it's going to get in Arizona.  The staff is friendly and the food is great.  The restaurant is huge and can accommodate large groups.  The restaurant itself probably needs some improvement - new chairs, tables, high chairs, etc. but I enjoy coming out here anyway!

RPDfYh-sc_AL8DOOwTHyJg.text: WARNING: C-fu is closed and a new place called Golden Crown has taken its place. Food is not very good and service reminds me of food stalls in a typical China town. Very disappointed. After 20 years of good memories of Cfu, we will not be going back.

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States

WwUHkvRf_BQ-LaeQr8tJnQ.text: Gourmet? I think not. First off ordered a beer. They brought a bottle and a plastic cup. Portions were big. Average taste. WARNING: This place apparently uses MSG my wife was very sick about 4 hours after we ate.

s8W4XtYJEjMsQEKU3FTylw.text: Worst food. Every dish that was suppose to come hot was very cold. The noodle dishes weren't cooked enough because the noodles were hard and the food was not hot. Will not be coming back. The servers did not care one bit about the service.

ZjF3CwnutN61-I1FyEhTlw.text: I love Dim Sum and this place is super cheap. I hear the regular food is amazing. Sadly I haven't tried that. I will always come back here cause the food is cheap and good. I will miss this place. Service is not always the best. Sometimes you want the food cart to come around and it never comes to you...  But what can you expect from an authentic chinese place huh. lol

IgBs7qyLKRym1WwkM_yOxQ.text: Just  had a great dim sum experience.  There were 12 of us for their dim sum lunch on Saturday.  Everyone enjoyed the quality and variety of offerings.  I had called ahead for reservations as I wanted to be sure they could accommodate all 12 of us at one table.  No problem, the table was ready when we arrived.  Having a lazy Susan as the center of the table, makes it easy to distribute the food.  The various carts filled with goodies are continuously circling the room so you can pace your eating and select the things that appeal to you.  All of the food was well prepared and met or exceeded our expectations.  If there is a negative its that with several carts all with different varieties of food, there is too little time between the carts to select and eat before the next cart is there.  All of us enjoyed the experience and several were surprise at how reasonably priced the meal was. Definitely a fun meal.

72fpARKa6uSKcMIfAIgyYw.text: I used to love coming here for dim sum. I fear this will be my last visit for a while.   The place was near empty this morning. For a Saturday, this was a bit of a surprise. The prices have gone up while the selection had gone down. I only saw one full cart the whole time. One poor server pushed around a cart of the same eight items the whole time I was there - including a sad dish of cold clams.  The gai lan was still delicious but the steamed char sui buns were nowhere to be seen. Since this was my friends' favorite dish, she was left disappointed. The baked buns are now larger but contain less pork.  For what you pay for three sugar cane shrimp balls, you'd think they would be served hot, or warm, or anything but cold. I asked for the haupia (coconut pudding), I wondered why they were now cutting it in wedges. What I was served was a sour milk spongy dessert.   The new owner hovered, and prodded his employees along, which was a bit distracting. The chair covers look nice but that's definitely not the improvement you hope to find.

jivWaPku87at7XwGfF-G4A.text: Food was okay but 2 stars is for the service. We went on a Sunday for Father's Day and decided to try something new. The waitresses were just plan rude and unhelpful and once they delivered our food they didnt came back to check on us. We should have known this place was horrible because there were only a few people. Its such a big place but no customers. We will never go back. We plan to stay with Mekong Palace in Mesa.

4jXYdRJFc7_4gJGWo-eWRw.text: This used to be one of my favorite places for dim sum.  Not sure what happened but this place is old and tired.

QodgK9zCvARsIwIahACjOA.text: Used to love coming here for dim sum, but realized something was different on our last visit. Looking on here I see they have changed owners. Too bad. The man working at the front seating people was incredibly rude. Once seated we had to wait for 15-20 minutes before 1 dim sum cart came by. They were out in the dining room, just ignored us. Food wasn't as good as it used to be. So sad!

a0henEgGwzCg93Ymx6v8cw.text: i have been going to c-fu since it first opened and it has always been my favorite chinese restaurant but when I went yesterday for dim sum it was very disappointing.  The selection was smaller than I am used to seeing there and the dim sum was cold in every case and bland tasting.  The sliced bbq pork was overcooked and nearly tasteless.  I  went early in the lunch hour on saturday so food should not have been cold.   I  hope it was an aberration and I'll probably give them another chance.

GTKDO-cPpsh_1js1C0WVUw.text: I have three go-to spots for dim sum in Phoenix - Great Wall, Phoenix Palace, and C-Fu Gourmet.  They all have their pros and cons, but C-Fu has won me over with their service.  They're the only one of the three who have staff who are courteous and make the effort to speak to you in English.  However, food-wise they're more or less on par.  The dishes at C-Fu sometimes look re-heated, but that might be because I'm not a morning person and don't make it in til 1PM or so.  But it's still pretty damn good.  Great Wall has really good barbecue pork buns, but are always jam-packed on any given day, so be prepared to wait outside for about 15 minutes for your number to be called - keeping in mind that 15 minutes in the summer heat feels like an eternity.  Phoenix Palace has pretty good egg tarts, but can get pretty crowded too and have some rather rude waiters.  So if you wanna try dim sum, I'd recommend trying out all three to try their best dishes.  If you don't want to have the experience ruin your day, go to C-Fu.

UqbnLXb81lhZBLrjtHjTSQ.text: For 10-15 years C-Fu used served the best dim sum in the valley. What happened?  I went about four times a year and it compared favorable to the best in other cities. About two years ago, all that changed. The pork dumplings were served under cooked and everything was mediocre.   I've tried all the other places in Phoenix and none are as good as the old C-Fu.  Sadly, C-Fu is still terrible. I go by myself once in a while hoping for better news, my family won't go with me - no good news to report.   The other places are better.  But we concluded that Phoenix does not have its dim sum act together. Seattle, San Francisco, New York, even Minneapolis has good dim sum (Chicago not so much).   As dim sum aficionados, I would love someone to pick up the gauntlet and do something special.

OUrDlxaMlsWfvziYvjuZTg.text: Come here Sunday's for dim sum. The staff is very quick to offer a wide variety of delicious food.  Usually have a group of from 5 to 10 people and that works very well.  The lazy Susan on the table makes passing plates and sharing easy and comfortable.

j1_ZCFg7RAot0xA33GY87A.text: Chinese New Years at C-fu Gormet is a tradition for my family. Its something we look forward to every year. We have been seeing it for about nine years strait now. But after this year, I feel we will not be going back. We came in and got a table pretty quick. However, I had to go to the bathroom. Yuk. Two stalls were out of order and I had to scavenge for toilet paper around the unkept restroom. Bad start to the evening.   So we are waiting for the lion dancers. And soon they came. But they were just sitting there. What were they waiting for? No biggie. We ordered and the food was on its way. But we waited. And waited. And waited. I was hoping for something to happen. Food? Lion dancing? What would come first? A cart full of ice water! Yay.  So then the lion dancers started to stir. Some kids were playing with their equipment. Cute. The dancers were very nice to them and let them explore the lions and take pics and bang on the drums. Then finally they would start. Two lions go to the front. No food yet, but this should be cool.   Then the rudest thing I ever saw happened. The guy who was pushing the water cart runs over to the drummer lady, demands her drumsticks (I distinctly heard her say "no") then takes them from her and starts drumming. The people in the lions peeked out wondering what the heck was going on. This was NOT part of the show apparently. Then I see the lion guys doing a ton of hand gestures to the drummer. And this poor girl is just shrugging her shoulders and pointing to the rude older bully man drumming as loud as he can. Wow. Finally he stopped and gave the sticks back to the drummer and marches off. WTF? At least the kids were polite enough to ask to play with the equipment. He just barged in and demanded.  So the drummer starts and the lions start moving. Then our food arrives! It was hot and fresh and crispy (sesame chicken) with good flavor. The other dishes then arrived for the rest of the family soon after. They were just as well prepared. No complaints from all the others. It took a little longer that it should but I guess it was worth it. We really enjoyed the lion dancing. Once they finally got to start.  The prices also seemed a bit more than usual. But we paid and left a small tip anyways.  Bottom line. Rude servers. Dirty bathroom. Awesome lion dancing and ok food. Reading previous reviews I see that they are under new management. I hope they take stock in these reviews to better themselves and live up to the previous reputation of C-Fu Gormet.

erzKuPInAhC5uTcmy-pAUg.text: Wow went in yesterday and sat down to have some Dim sum.. The selection has gone down with new owner and the servers wow disrespectful .  we sat they ask what do we want to drink ...(note the place is really never busy.) I asked what kind of ice tea do you have and the girl said in a smart manner we only have one kind.. My son step in and said he asking what kind like flavor she said jasmine .. Then she said do you want it or not .. I stopped her right there and said please don't be a smart a** and we did what we do and what everyone should do we got up and left ... Wonder why business is dead...

eHQFZmdU_kAQE1-uAyZRwg.text: I'm crushed to have to write this review.  C-Fu has been a family tradition since before we relocated here over 11 years ago.  It was one of the first restaurant foods my son ever ate, and has been a favorite all these years.  But today, we have to say goodbye to our old haunt.  It seems there has been an ownership change, and while that would not stop us from returning (for sentimental reasons, obviously), the significant decline in the service and food quality has.  We visited Sunday during lunch, typically a busy time.  The place was almost empty.  The dim sum carts have mostly been replaced with industrial carts, and nearly all of the food we got was cold.  The barbecue pork was obviously old, and made us sick to our stomachs. Based on other recent reviews, I can't blow it off as a fluke.  It was a good run, but all good things must come to an end.  Bye, C-Fu.  Thanks for the memories.

yjw1HsIx7z9ToXWmcqieHQ.text: Not worth the drive.  Dim sum tastes as it it were frozen the day before and steamed.  Maybe the menu dishes are better in quality but don't come here for dim sum.

WHb_aWIU2GUP4kCa7qqsxQ.text: This was our favorite restaurant especially for dim sum. However with the change of owners, we will no longer visit this restaurant.   The service was simply horrible. The restaurant was near empty with many servers mulling around doing everything but attending to customers.  After taking our order, our server disappeared for the rest of our dining experience.  Another couple a few tables away had the same issue trying to locate their server.  The food left much to be desired.  The seaweed vegetable soup was OK, although my companion found it to be bland.  The duck was dry and they forgot to serve any sauce with it.  The spicy garlic eggplant was acceptable, although not as spicy as one would expect.  The biggest disappointment was the vegetarian vegetable noodles (Hong Kong style).  The dish had way too much sauce, resulting in the noodles getting soggy.

kHomDdoG5rMs_RqvYHtQOQ.text: Worst possible experience. There was a table that left just before we sat down and it was empty, hint number one. It took about 20 minutes for us to get 5 cups of water, hint number two. After we ordered we received our first dish in 1.5hrs, hint number three.   This place may be under new management, but they need to get their heads out of their rear. Leaving a table unattended for that long period of time is only acceptable if 1. The place is on fire and emergency crews are outside 2. The place is packed and there was a line out the door(nope not even close to full capacity) or 3. The chef had a heart attack and keeled over the stove and has started the fire. To put the cherry on top the "cook" came out and survived the floor a couple of times.  Just a few choice words for the the management: please, please improve your service! Until then I DO NOT believe I will EVER be coming back again.

xVCPQtWN4mLQe3uA1kvFwg.text: Friendly service. Just doesn't compare to dim sum in Cali.

jTh9Vi6UbzrQavqV1MFENg.text: We are leaving here hungry. So disappointed. All they had was dumplings and soup at Dim Sum. Asked multiple times for veggies and meat selections. Leaving now to get some lunch.

DCL3phIFJwLgAtYrPeHrRA.text: Went there for Dim Sum on the Chinese New Year and got to see a show with dragons and drum players as well as have an incredible meal. The selection of food at the dim sum is amazing and every dish was very tasty. We will definitely be returning.

OZJXzn5Vd0nf-daxnsz-Bw.text: I was invited to a banquet dinner for about 50 to 60 people.  Problem is the place didn't provide mircrophones so the organizer's were speaking loudly to get audience's attention.  The tables were spaced very far from each other.  The organizer's pre-selected the dishes for the dinner:  Miced Beef Soup - It was ok the cilatro over powered the taste of the soup Hong Kong Walnut Shrimp - The walnuts were not fresh Sliced Abalone with Black Mushrooms - Good taste  Whole Roasted Duck - The duck was very fatty (more than normal) Beef and Black Pepper - It was ok, a little bland Pork Chop with Peking Sauce - This dish was the best Salted Fish and Chicken Fried Rice - The lettuce was not finely cut, so the large chucks made the dish soggy Fish fried and stir fried - This was very good  Why the 2 stars?  The service sucked!  They didn't tell you what dish it is when they bring it out.  And you wait forever for refills.  And when someone on the our table asked for a bag, they pointed to the station for us to get it ourselves.  And the place was SUPER HOT!  The air kicked on every once in awhile.  Didn't expect to eat in 90 degree weather.

AyS6yOVLKh7y0T0TiYL_UA.text: My wife & I came here for dim sum because our favorite place in Mesa was so overcrowded, & we were hungry. All dim sum items we selected at C-Fu Gourmet were so bland I had to use a lot of soy sauce just to have some flavor.  "Gourmet" should not be part of their name.   I don't plan to go back to this restaurant any time soon.

CwysIj7UhFDtODd9iY4YIQ.text: So I haven't been here for dimsum, like everyone else seems to be reviewing, so I guess I"ll clarify...   My review is for their dinner menu.  A friend and I had dinner last week and we ended up at C-Fu because I was in the mood for some authentic Chinese.  Well, he's Chinese (kinda - haha) and recommended this restaurant because he grew-up coming here with his parents.    We ordered some dumplings, which they steamed for us, a spicy pork chop dish and then I ordered my favorite which wasn't on the menu, sauteed fish filet in black bean sauce.  All of the food was good and they were very nice in accommodating my special order.  I'd reorder any of the dishes we had again, and I really loved having left-overs the next day. :)  See ya there!

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Pork Chops something - very tasty!
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Special order - sauteed fish in black bean sauce... delish!

tmE-r2kRcgT74ZhmgmKP2g.text: This place has an air of faded grandeur, like it used to be nice. Now the slip covers over the back of the chairs can't cover up the little shabby details. I didn't expect much, and that's what I got.  We ordered 5 appetizers: egg rolls, crab rangoons, fried shrimp, crispy quail, and chicken lettuce wraps. Food came out in stages, the first 3 arriving quickly, served with pots of sweet and sour, spicy mustard, and pepper flakes in oil. The pots were dirty. The egg rolls were overcooked but were otherwise pretty standard. The shrimp was cook right. The rangoons were also fine, as far as plain and uninspired rangoons go. The quail came out next, completely dry. But crispy, anyway. The chicken for the lettuce wraps had almost no flavor; you had to pour on plum sauce for it to taste like anything. The lettuce cups were full of water; I shook one off for a minute or 2 and it was still dripping on me.   Service is fast and friendly; prices are decent. Basically a totally average Chinese place.

JJhWhhgX1q9NNLb7EtToAw.text: This place is my favorite spot for dim sum on the weekends. They have a lot of variety of items and of course to start bringing them by as soon as you're seated. It's very large inside and I've never had to wait for a table no matter how large my group was. The dinner menu is just as good, and the food is well-prepared. One of my favorite spots and definitely worth a visit if your looking for good Chinese restaurant that is far better than the average take-out place.

ODRjCxcwUGjwyhWOjBoE-Q.text: The restaurant is under new management.  The staff are very friendly and the food is delicious.  However, the bathrooms really need to be cleaned more frequently.  I have been twice and both times the bathrooms needed attention.  If it wasn't for the bathroom discomfort, I would have rated this restaurant with 5 stars.

-bfO84t9p5WzZgJq3ptbnw.text: I heard good thing about this place and thought I will go try their dim sum, so when I went there on a friday afternoon for my dim sum crave ...   Growing up in Hong Kong, I can tell what good dim sum is ... and this place is definitely not. Ordered the 'Ha gow' (shrimp dumpling) and 2 other dim sum ... and it was just bad ... the skin was way too thick and too sticky that you can not even bite it in ... and the seasoning for the other dishes simply not right ... It was so bad that me and my friends decided to get the bill and go to another dim sum place (China King) to continue our meal.  Beside the food, the service was not good either ... I can hear the waitress was making comments that we only ordered 3 things (good/bad thing to know a 2nd language sometime) ...  Definitely won't come back to this place

7NgvcnzBL39uVVLIis1uCg.text: Like the egg noodle stir fry a lot (they get it crispy, which is rare, it's usually soaked in oil), the sweet rolls filled with the custard are soooo delicious and I can't find them anywhere in so cal it seems. It's crowded and the place to be if you're an Asian living in this area and quite a fun experience if you're not (Asian ).Otherwise, it's pretty run-of-the-mill food and kind of pricey for the quality and location.

88GnYqWYlzIWGVB5mGzbTQ.text: I'm pretty sure this is the only place in Chandler that serves Dim Sum.  Although it's the only option, it's a pretty good option.  I recommend having Dim Sum here on the weekends.  During Saturday and Sunday, they offer a pretty extensive Dim Sum menu.  I pride myself in being an adventurous eater, and this is the perfect place for people like me.  They have the usual Dim Sum fare, but they also have dishes like jellyfish, tripe soup, chicken feet, etc.. It may seem a little intimidating to a newcomer, so ask a person at the next table for recommendations if you need it.    The regular menu is pretty good as well.  I have dined here with my family for years.  This is a perfect place to have a family gathering.  You can have a nice hearty and delicious dinner for 12 people for less than $100, and that includes drinks a bunch of food left over to take home.  My favorite dishes here are:  Beef Westlake Style Soup. Salty Fish and Chicken Fried Rice Hong Kong Style Pan Fried Noodles Peking Duck Peking Pork Chops Fried Flounder w/ Black Bean Sauce Spicy Eggplant w/ Tofu  The staff is always friendly.  As with all Dim Sum style restaurants, don't be afraid to flag down the cart lady, and if that doesn't work, flag down the waitress and tell her what you want.  They always seem willing to help in the event that you get skipped over in the rotation.  In the event that you are in need of banquet service, this is a very viable option.  I had 85+ people come celebrate my wife's birthday a few years ago, and this restaurant did not disappoint.  All I actually had to do was call a week in advance, let them know my budget, choose the dishes, and make the payment.  They took care of everything else.  It was nice and easy and I took credit for it all.

gGtF3ooKnTvqKnd1Upcwdw.text: I don't think I have anything bad to say about this place. I really like it and I love that it's big enough that we really never have to wait 45 min to get a table. The servers are very friendly. The food is yum always gets me stuffed and satisfied. I am sure there are other dim sum places but I think this one is usually my first choice restaurant is clean and I love that the owner is always there helping out his employees.

jKzsNXN1QjWyodSVvTg_3Q.text: Honestly writing this review because I use to love this place for dim sum. It has taken a drastic turn downhill from what I'm use to. I came in at around 11 am for dim sum (1130 is basically prime time for when all the good dim sum is out) and got my normal order of hargao, shrimp in rice noodles and spicy wontons. All dishes were lukewarm which is astonishing to me. It's supposed to be served hot! My absolute favorite hargao had the disgusting texture of mush which would horrify anyone trying it for the first time, and my rice noodles with shrimp was soggy and had a horrible sauce with it. Honestly this review is a reality check for this restaurant. Get your stuff together!

Dihb5vETuyqxwFATBW0ZgA.text: I'm disappointed. The first time I came here was a Tuesday about 11AM. Open, humongous banquet hall, no one around. Yesterday came around for dim sum. This time it was open. The meal I had was, as we might say, ma ma fu fu, not so c-fu! Everything was hot. There were a lot of lofaan here enjoying it, which is nice since everything on the carts was declared in English, but there was a mix of Mandarin and Cantonese speakers among the staff and clearly some who spoke neither. The calamari had the appearance of being , but it was just fried calamari that you could get at any bar or restaurant. I could be wrong, but this might have been previously factory made frozen dim sum. In any event, I had some distress later that afternoon. Staff was nice, but this experience is not targeted for natives, I think.

iBcoD8m_NIkyxT7k8c0AeQ.text: I've been coming here for dim sum for years, and while it's had its ups and downs, it still remains my favorite dim sum spot in Phoenix, mostly because of their selection. My favorites are the taro, crispy shrimp balls, shrimp balls on the sugar cane, ha cao and xiu mai. Yea it's a little greasy, but what do you expect when you're going for dim sum?

T10PM7PfpJIyIvNi_-4BZg.text: Ordered pick-up food.  Service was speedy and food tasted great.  Would definitely come back for a sit-in dinner.

77FL4HkytZW0rIzu7gc4eg.text: Almost makes me feel like home in San Francisco.  I come here for the dim-sum, tasty treats, Chinese tapas, appetizers if you will.  They have a good selection and will easily have whatever they don't immediately have rolling around in the carts made for you.   Pricing is fair.  Service is friendly and decor is straight out of SF dim-sum palaces.  My favorites: pot stickers and steamed Cha siu bao's (pork bun).

oOJ9X7QP-gBDDAvZmgieYQ.text: Good place for Dim Sum.  They have many options that you can pick from their carts. The steamed green veggies are never over cooked (nice balance if you get a lot of the fried things). Various pot stickers, dumplings and other dishes that are all delish. You pay by the plate, and at the end you take the check to the front and pay. Best to sample a bunch of things and share with your party.

F-UwvouRrOLbBUA3e_iW6A.text: I've been to C-Fu on numerous occasions. We even had our rehearsal dinner there and the owner was very courteous and did a great job delivering us a custom menu.  Recently, the day after my brother's wedding, we had a huge party and were thinking about all going out to dinner, we decided to call up C-Fu and they told us that there wouldn't be any waiting at all. They quickly took care of us all and then we all decided to hit up the bar and do karaoke. It was a blast.

u9DMrVIDkHos8CnHDcsU8Q.text: I came here for dimsum with a few friends during lunch. The quality of the food is mediocre compared the legit ones in Hacienta Heights, CA or San Gabriel, CA. My friend and I are hardcore dimsum fans, so we have been to this dimsum a few times, until we decided to change to the one across the street called Phoenix Palace Buffet.   For some reason, we returned back to C-Fu to try it again, but the service was horrible!! We requested water and tea, and in my water cup and all around it were white residue from a previous mixed drink of another customer. I had already drank half of the iced water and realized there was all over the sides of the cup. I immediately asked for a replacement and even the server was grossed out! They did not do anything to compensate for such a gross encounter, which in the end made everyone at the table lose our appetites. Seriously... traumatized. Definitely not coming back until their service improves!

Rgmez-zeNeWJrP19PVyvNQ.text: Great dim sum!  Go on Sunday for brunch/lunch!  Favorites that I always order: Shrimp dumplings Bean curd rolls Shrimp or beef noodle wraps Snow buns for dessert  If you're brave, try the chicken feet.  It's a traditional plate that is delicious as long as you can get over the fact that you're eating feet.  If you're Asian, you should have been born over it.  haha  Drink tea with your dim sum!  It's not right any other way.  The owner/manager comes around during dim sum time to make sure you got all the goodies you wanted.  If not, he goes and grabs it from the cart especially for you!  How nice of him!  I've been here for dim sum, with one occasion for dinner.  Everything was tasty!  There aren't as many traditional choices that would be found in the bay area or LA (California), but this is the best place in the Pheonix/Mesa area for Chinese food so far.

DRNTBCd03txi9kJ4qSDuVA.text: This is by far my family's favorite go to spot for dim sum. We absolutely love it and take friends and family as often as possible. They have a better selection on the weekend. Yum!

RFdjhHQVmrByJuYqt95c1g.text: I've been here more times than I can count, but for some reason I am only now thinking to write a review. Until today (when we returned to that other place near Lee Lee's), the last four or five times we have had dim sum we have gone to C-Fu. The reason is simple. You go on Sunday, which for those not in the know is prime dim sum territory, and you are seated and served right away. No lines, no waiting on the carts, no "shu mai is coming" (it seems like most places run out that early even though they must know it is one of the most popular dishes), and fairly attentive service.   Why C-Fu when they food might be slightly better across the street? Well, the quality has gone down a bit. C-Fu which, by the way, was one of the first places to offer dim sum in the Valley, and one of the first around to offer "real" Chinese food, seems to,  once in awhile, rest on their laurels and ease up on yummy-ness. However, the food is still not bad and, because of new competition and the slight decrease in quality, you can get in, get food, and get out quickly. For that, their history, and their quick service, I still give them four stars. I just hope they take the food up a little notch in the future so they can return to their place as the premier Chinese restaurant in the area.

TsSR441cokCH5K_SSZKqrg.text: Place is a hidden gem. All things Chinese are at their finest. Looks like a wedding hall because they use it for one at least twice a month. They have the access to some of the freshest seafood / produce/ ect. available, with there location so close to lee's market place which flies in fish and other Asian inspired staples daily. Plus lee's has special selections for near by restaurants.   They have the whole gamete of edible creatures available. From jelly fish to duck. And there recipes bring them to their best. Everything is family style, so bring friends/family for great food and conversation. There is a bar, but not really a place where your looking to drink. I think it's there just for the wedding/events they put on.   It is a culture shock. So don't get all weird if there is a language barrier or if you not use to a rotating Asian condiment tray iin the middle of a family style table. That is what makes it so special. If you have issues with that buy Rosetta Stone and get over it.

phw06OUo8Q-xuZga_R6Pyw.text: We went in for Dim-sum this morning, an hour after they opened, and no carts or food we around, service was slow.  I left to go to Phoenix Palace across the road where the carts were ready for business and the staff were attentive.

YvxZASku93_EGF1L8QWsGA.text: This is a review for dinner. Came here for dinner with a group party.    We chose C-Fu cause it was spacious enough to allow us a private party.  We requested arrangements for karaoke and stage.  We had a blast!   The service was excellent and the food was very good and very authentic.   The owners offered us crab with tamarine sauce, which was a fresh change from the usual ginger garlic sauce.  Crab was excellent.   Now I'm bummed cause I don't know anyone else who makes crab with that secret sauce!  The walnut prawns were delicious and quickly devoured.    Gailon & mushrooms and other dishes were spot on and far better than I would have expected to find in Phoenix.    It was the perfect place for our family gathering.   Will return to try the dim sum and will definitely keep C-Fu in mind for future dinner banquets.

gxxv0-1Zm8OBehIP7VL1tg.text: This place is not the best place to get dim sum, the food is mediocre as well as the service.  My biggest complaint is they try to gip you. The cashier cheated my mother change. She was supposed to get back $44 and a few cents. She only gave my mom $40 back. Then as my boyfriend and I were saying our goodbyes, the cashier comes running out screaming at us in Chinese I believe. We couldnt understand her at all. We kept saying sorry we don't understand. She kept speaking loudly. My mother had paid, she got short changed, we walked out the door and she came to chase us down for a tip. Like she demanded a tip right there and then. I should have said no thank you but gave her $10. I feel as that was very unprofessional and a bad practice for such a business. We are not obligated to tip. Our water was not being filled, my main dish came at the end that I ordered and by then I was full eating everything else.

KgQ0m-iFYPSl8_HzbCslyQ.text: This is a disgusting place because the meat inside wasn't cooked all the way. Not even the 5 letter word "sorry" came out of the waiters mouth. Family member was traumatized when she bit into it and swallowed it, then to find out it wasn't cooked. She was worried  and started bawling. The manager acted like he didn't speak English. But, if you want raw meat, this place is perfect for you to stuff your mouth!

tWgnv4zT60_6iuNP6YvCWA.text: Undercooked pork!!!  My wife took me here as she is Asian and lives all things Asian except lucky for me she like me not Asian!  She loves hot pot places and taking me to all things Asian...  We came here for lunch about a year ago and I had never been here.  I have no idea what the food is when they walk around and say you want some... This being said I do not like pork, I do not want to eat it as it is dirty to me...  I got some sort of what I thought was a meatball which turned out to be pork balls complete with blood dripping on my plate.   I was done....  I lost my appetite and never went back.  Nobody asked if the food was good or why my food was nearly untouched...   No thanks!

8x3jFnoiHGboSn3H4CONLw.text: Absolutely terrible. Pork was raw, the egg drop soup was terrible, everything looked old, Had weird colors. smelt off putting. I have an iron stomach and the food over powered that... I vomited not even 15 mins after consuming it. Didn't touch 1/4 of the stuff they gave us and was still charged for it(?) Not very welcoming people either, Lady made rude comment about not eating the food, sorry but i don't want food poisoning...

azFdnF4stj8H1gdokGnO-A.text: Dim sum in Phoenix? YUP and it was delish!   My top 3 were: 1) eggplant with shrimp 2) rice wrapped in the leaf 3) spicy wonton  I really liked how they actually cook the eggplant, taro cake, and chive dumpling right in front of you. So when you bite it, it's piping hot! Apparently they used to do this back in the day back home but I don't remember.  I thought the other typical dumplings like the hau gau and shu mai were just okay. The Chinese broccoli was also a little over cooked but overall the good definitely out weighted the bad. I will definitely come back and try more.   Don't forget to rub the buddha's belly!

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Nice and fresh!
Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States

2RDPNNlG91Bld8I4ZgNaDA.text: Came to a wedding reception here and I cannot believe they had the audacity to host a wedding and event receptions in one room. The other party ended up fighting with our MC. How distasteful.

Jmh2ouBht5ssg0FfAji-9w.text: We visited C-Fu on a Saturday evening and there are only one other table seated out of the 20-30 empty tables. We ordered muchu pork. The muchu wraps on first bite smell rotten vegetable like from a garbage dump. I took the meat filling out separately and it tasted okay. When I mentioned the fact to the waitress, she said it was the flour used in the wrapping. I disagreed. Another server passer-by mentioned that it may be due to the vegetable bat choy, which I agreed is rotten and smelling like decomposing garbage. I believe this would be a health hazard for anybody eating this. A visit from the Health Department would be helpful for the sake of the clients. E Coli or other infectious origins would be likely. Fof the sake of your health, I highly would not recommend this restaurant due to the hazardous food preparation standards putting the public in great danger.

jvwnBclKcZ9TKzvL0EJQng.text: New management, same old habits. Service is extremely slow. Came in just before 7pm got seated right away, but waited at least 15 min before anyone even came back to us. My uncle had to get up and put in our order, sitting here now a total of 45 min while I write this review and still have yet to receive our soup. A table came in 20 min after us has already had their soup. There doesn't seem to be enough workers to cover the entire restaurant. Few kids are constantly running around the place as well as up and down the stage. Rule one of restaurant etiquette, control your kids!  The food was pretty good though, not sure if it was cause we were super hungry by the time the food came. Today being Chinese New Years they had a special treat with some lion dancers. Other than that because of the slow service this place is a no go for me.

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Family dinner style food

skgqjFQe_qxsInzkI3SPMA.text: Food wasn't good.  Service was bad and the place looks dirty. Dim sum was cold and there was not much selection. Not a pleasant dining experience.

pefPBEN_7liLiF_Qe8lnkw.text: As far as dim sum goes, C-Fu has always been the last option for me.  While the restaurant itself is definitely had better days and has an air of out dated elegance, the food is pretty white-washed and Americanized.    If I am to drag myself out of bed for dim sum on my precious weekend, I expect hot steamy food and delicious steam to waft over me.  Instead, the food is always mediocre and warm at best.  Don't arrive too early for dim sum or you'll get the leftover steamers from the prior day.  While their food isn't downright disgusting, the targeted audience has definitely changed the past few years.  I say come around 11pm so you get the fresh dishes of the day.   I will say that their custard buns are probably the best --- specifically the pineapple baos.

sl7lUZ21zHfDMBYAxgALlg.text: We've been coming here for years and it's been a family favorite for dim sum.  I'm sad to write this review but there is no denying that everything has gone downhill.  The chairs are filthy,  the tables are chipped and worn out.  The cleanliness of this place has always been hit or miss but we overlooked that because the food was good.  Today,  the food was terrible.  Nothing was hot,  several things were ice cold.  Cold gummy dumplings...ick. I watched two employees 'clean' a table,  just gross. We used to wait a long time for a table here, the last few times we've visited the dining room has been virtually empty.  We hoped they'd turn it around; unfortunately,  today will be our last visit.

458fbaEXPimbQpVSHRJL0A.text: If it were possible to give a lower rating than merely 1 star, I would give a negative rating of minus 12.  The restaurant was filthy!  We had a large party of 11 people and had to wait almost 2 hours for our Luke warm dishes to be served   Half our group walked out  The owners of this establishment should be both embarrassed and ashamed!  Will NEVER step through their door again

wpN0cD-sTCMnhd8yLsjA8g.text: Pleasant service. Very delicious spicy eggplant. Large dining room. This seemed a little impersonal. The best eggplant I've had in a long time. My new fav. Thanks for reading. The Bike Chaplain

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Delicious eggplant. Earthy spicy flavors. Yum

VovnbJYauzwqPJaggZZMTQ.text: I went to this place on last Saturday 5/5/18 for my friend's wedding reception and I could not believe that the restaurant booked another event (seem to be like some kind of company conference) at the same time in the SAME restaurant. Beside the noise coming from the other event, when the wedding ceremony is running, one lady from the other event walked to us and complained about the wedding is TOO LOUD (whose weeding that do not play music?). The MC told her to talk to the restaurant's manager but she was just staying there and kept complaining about the noise we are making. WTH. ITS A WEDDING LADY. YOU SHOULD NOT RUIN PEOPLE WEDDING LIKE THAT. After 15 minutes fight, she decided to leave and left the bride, groom and the guesses feeling weird and awkward. The restaurant should not book 2 different kinds of event like that in one night and until now, according to the bride, they did not even apologize or do anything about that event. I will never book any event here nor come here to eat anymore with this poor management.

9z3u8tbtUV-IppOnz5H3pA.text: Don't ever come to this place!!! It's not even worth my one star! I had an awful experience here that no words could describe how suck it was. I had a reservation for wedding party 4 months ago & have requested it to be private, but they secretly booked another conference event & not even let me know, just 2 weeks before the wedding. The manager convinced me that the other party won't stay long & won't play music, just talking only. I HAD NO CHOICES, BUT ANGRILY ACCEPTED because it was too late to change! But then I WAS TRULY SHOCKED when i came to the wedding. It was crowded & loud on the other side. Additionally, when we started to play music, a lady from the other side came & yelled at us that we had to turn off the music. it showed how unprofessional they were when the managers stood on a side did nothing to stop the fight. Nevertheless, nobody served the beers even when we paid $80 a case. The food wasn't good & a lot of left over, so the service. THE MANAGERS DID NOT SAY A WORD EVEN AN APOLOGIZE. IT WAS A NIGHTMARE that nobody in that night want to remember. PLS REMEMBER THAT Don't ever hold 2 different parties at the same time for any reasons if you don't want this to happen again otherwise just close the business!

8xgrn1YeFMDTWx4AGMoOlQ.text: This is an interesting restaurant. It is huge like a banquet hall and there is a stage with the disco ball.  I have been here for dim sum and it is really good. Lots of choices and you don't have to wait long for a cart with a new item to come by your table.  Last night though, I went there just for dinner. One thing I noticed is that the menu is in Chinese and English and there is no explanation provided about any entree.  So, if you don't know what something is or you wonder what ingredients are in a dish, you have to ask your server. Given that their menu is quite long, I think asking your server what each dish is, is a little crazy.  It is definitely an "authentic" Chinese restaurant, where most of the conversation amongst patrons is in Chinese. There are also things on the menu that Americanized Chinese restaurants simply don't have--like salted cod fried rice.   For me, it's not the best Chinese food I've had. See my review on Desert Jade for the best Chinese food. But I would go back here again especially for dim sum.

ypbiqVJSQAmsNZPEm6W3KQ.text: I remember going to C-Fu Gourmet for Dim Sum 10 years ago and now that we've moved back to Arizona I was so excited to go back until my mother-in-law said they no longer do Dim Sum.  So I trusted her and went to China King for Dim Sum until they closed down.  I was so sad until our friends said Mekong palace does Dim Sum so we went there few times.  I wasn't impressed but beggars can't be choosers.  This Easter Sunday I was craving for Dim Sum so we got up early and went to Mekong at 10:00am.  This place was so packed and the line was so long we had waiting time of 1 to 2 hours.  I said no way and we left Mekong.  My mood was terrible.  My husband said let's just try C-Fu Gourmet for lunch instead.  He was hoping my mood would improve with some yummy greasy Chinese food...   And it did!!! When these amazing Dim Sum aroma welcomed me to their restaurant.  We set right front of the kitchen door and it was WONDERFUL.  We got fresh pickings of all the Dim Sums.  I was sad when dessert cart came over without my favorite Egg tarts but my disappointment didn't last long.  Wonderful serving lady said don't worry I got you.  When Egg tarts came out she stopped at our table first with these hot and yummy tarts.  I was so full by then but my wonderful husband said let's share one and take the others to go.  I am so happy to find C-Fu Gourmet does Dim Sum and they do Dim Sum every day according to the cashier.  Best Easter Sunday Ever:)

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Dim Sum time at C-Fu Gourmet

b2yndXvG5Rb18kc50fmQqQ.text: I heard there was new management recently , so my family came for dinner.  The sizzling rice soup was on point . We also got the roast duck which came out nice,  flavorful, and crisp (no sauce though.  For best saucy duck, try diamonds in Phoenix). Finished our meal with a streaming seafood tofu pot. Seafood was fresh and the tofu was pump with piping hot sauce. Ohmyyyy. Drooling a bit just thinking about it.   Definitely worth a try if you haven't been to CFu for dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Seafood tofu pot.

oJzcQBV2WCfDpmrn9oQzaw.text: On Christmas Day, any open restaurant must be busy. C-Fu was definitely busy, not busy as the other dim sum spot across the street, but still busy. My family and I were seated and I asked a fellow server if the server could ask someone to change the television channel to a basketball game on ABC. The server's response, "We're quite busy right now and we don't have time for that." Having experience in the service industry, I was appalled by his response, as were my family around the table.  I give C-Fu one star because the dim sum, or at least the ones they offered, were fairly flavored. But as for customer service, I give it ZERO stars.  Sincerely, First time Yelp poster.

XkkBWcDgOIejF5TfjbD-0w.text: DimSum wouldn't be my reference here, but I'd like to give a 5 star for a new delish plate that I tried last Friday here with my fellows: Baked cat fish rolled with rice paper and mixed chili-tamarind-pepper sauce. The thing is, you have to call ahead to reserve this food because it can take some preparing times within 30-45mins. We ordered lobsters first, but then there were all baby minion lobsters so we might as well tried other specialties. I think we hit a jackpot when a party of 5 who ordered this came pretty late, so of course we had a pleasure to shorten the wait time for this one.  We arrived at 7pm, got seated right away in the middle of the pathway. We ordered crab meat and asparagus soup for appetizer, Singapore Mai for the add on, the baked fish, along with some boosters for a fun and warm night with friends.   The waitresses who served us were amazingly charming and friendly. They already knew what we wanted ahead of time without even have to clarify.   The soup is tasty as always, we had the selections of soy sauce, chili oil and pepper on the side in case we wanted some extra flavors. We didn't touch the Singapore Mai because we saved room for the main plate. And here we come, a giant big baked fish with numerous garnishes... My mouth is watery just to think about this delish plate. I forgot to mention the bill was pretty decent too.  Good food, good company, and greatest service ever. We will come back.

photos.caption: Photo of C-Fu Gourmet - Chandler, AZ, United States. Baked cat fish

VTzqJjLPR4rK-D4bgbINCw.text: all i can say is YUK and thats not a chinese  for terrible this is probley the most disgusting dim sum  ever  alot of deep fried dishes the place had a nasty stinge when i walked in on a high note the staff was quite friendly .....they better be for the food...and i use the term loosley ......they are serving

xgfwyktxDXMBMfMsHxQSGw.text: They have a good thing going here and they just don't know it or don't care about their customers.  Upon arriving the restaurant was dingy and crowded with people waiting.  I understand most Chinese restaurants are dingy, but some still have great food so I ignored the atmosphere.  We waited for about 10 minutes and were seated.  Once we were seated we saw about 8 open tables, but still a crowd of people waiting by the door.  Obviously, they don't manage seating their patrons very well.  The food was ok, not as good as Chinatown in Chicago.  Their dumplings and siopaio were tasty, but BBQ pork was fatty and dry like jerky.  Their servers were less than friendly and treated us like we were an inconvenience.  I'd go back to try some items on their menu, since some of their items were good.  The only reason I would go back is because it is hard to find authentic Chinese food near Scottsdale.  I will give them another chance also because their owner actually read my review and apologized for my bad experience.

Dtzo87bmSW-cfzviqHmk5g.text: hilarious! where did the screaming yellow  "....we reserve the right to add 15% gratuity to your bill....." signs go?  aka we know the service and dimsum sux, so we'll try and make money another way.  best dimsum in phoenix (pretty low standards for a desert community i guess)  luckily there's plenty of competition now in the east valley (hint: go 1 mi east, 1 mile  south) NW corner, get there before 11am on weekends or stand in line with the rest of the other asians.

70C8EggjiHmNdqs8T2rjsA.text: Food is okay considering we are in AZ.  Buyer beware!  They have a big sign on the counter where you pay the bill, saying that the 15% gratuity is NOT included in the total, yet they add it in anyway without your consent!  Shady!!!  Make sure you try to sit in the center, because if you are stuck sitting near the edge or closer to the room with the stage, the carts of food never seem to make it there!

Bow8cA7VCHc3-CuVd1UNiw.text: Love this place.  The hot sauce complemts every item. Kids like the constant dim sum action.

J6tNMtEYh-RW53IKolIRrA.text: Ever since the departing of the great Silver Dragon restaurant, (formerly located at 19th Ave. and Dunlap) I have been searching the valley for a place that could compare.  After months of salty beef chow fun, sub-par shrimp and walnuts, and no crispy chicken or duck, I was told to try this place.  The weirdo grocery store entrance opens into a strange reception area with a wall of statues.  The dining area is open and there is even a stage for karaoke!  The decor is very oriental restaurant-ish, but the tanks of fish and crustaceans are a nice touch.  It was refreshing to look over the menu and see every dish that I loved from our old Chinese restaurant.  My group ordered our standard Chinese dinner: sizzling rice soup, walnut shrimp, beef chow fun (dry), crispy chicken, kung pao chicken and fried rice.  Our soup arrived promptly and it was like a big warm chinese hug.  All the memories from Silver dragon came flooding back.  We had barely finished the soup when our food came rushing out, but that's what I expect from chinese food.  Words cannot describe the deliciousness that I experienced.  I had a bizarre flashback the moment the warm creamy shrimp and crunchy candied walnut hit my tongue.  I felt a tingle rush up my spine and I knew that I would be hooked on this restaurant.  The beef chow fun was a perfect balance of saltiness, meatiness, and the oh-so good charred/smokiness that comes from a fast stir-fry over a jet engine stove.  The crispy chicken was sublime combination of texture and taste.  And the kung pao was also good, but we order that just for some spice.  All in all, it was a surprisingly great dinner.  P.S. After the fantastic dinner, we went back for dim sum lunch and it was also unbelievable.  The place was packed with people but we got a table right away.  Immediately after we were seated the food frenzy started.  I was surprised at the wide array of dim sum offered, some of which I didn't think I could find outside of San Francisco.  The chicken feet were spicy, sweet, and tender.  The shrimp toasts were superbly buttery and crunchy.  The tripe soup was amazing.  The ha gau were delicate and perfectly balanced.  The Lotus-leaf rice was delicious.  And, the stuffed jalepenos were a spicy surprise, I had only had these with bell peppers but the jalepenos are a nice contrast to the sweet shrimp filling..  If you're searching for a chinese restaurant reminiscent of Grant Ave. this is it.

ENYIcxC9QBotkn76uWXZRA.text: Just went here on Christmas day. Arizona is not known for having any great Chinese restaurants. I honestly find Panda Express the only better quality Chinese food around locally. Mostly what you find are buffets, and I hate those. C Fu Gourmet is different. It's actually a real Chinese restaurant! It's located in a shopping center in Chandler with a handful of Asian businesses. This is a non-discript place, but once inside, you get the feel of a real Chinese restaurant. It has the fish tank and handi-crafts for sale, but the work force is Asian and the customers were mostly Asian and that's a really good sign. One thing you notice is the servers going around with carts that have daily specials on them. They go table to table and offer you to try the Dim Sum or other option. We ordered off the menu. I had the Kung Pau chicken meal that comes with rice, a spring roll, and  soup. I wasn't crazy about the soup. It was wonton and it was okay, but there was something about it that I didn't like, not sure what though. The Kung Pau chicken was awesome! It had just the right flavor and it was the perfect amount for one person. The spring roll was pretty good too. It wasn't oily which makes all of the difference with a spring roll. Had a great time and a great meal. I found the staff to be friendly and they answered all of our questions. I would go back again.

Ikq-ZNivW9-k05rqm0Hm5w.text: My boyfriend and I were wanting to try a new restaurant, after researching and seeing the reviews for C-Fu, we were sold. The restaurant setting itself was okay and we were seated right away. From ordering our beverages to ordering our food, the waitresses were nothing but short tempered and rude. One thing they need to do away with is their facial expressions, dead give away to your reactions of us needing more time, ladies. I was seriously blown away that we were treated with such disrespect. What really got me, was when my boyfriend was ordering his meal, the waitress wouldn't allow him to have Chow Mein noodles. She strictly told him to get Lo Mein. Which was very shocking and displeasing...and a big no no. Last time I checked it's all about pleasing the customers. If it's clearly on the menu, why isn't it able to be ordered? When it came to clearing the table, the waitress asked if we wanted boxes for the leftovers of our food, we replied "No thank you." But that wasn't clear enough, we got asked a second, third, and fourth time. We still said no thank you, with a few chuckles of uneasiness...and to that we got a nasty look thrown our way. I will never go back to this restaurant. I'd rather starve.

DK5oFFaMq3NnfgxvvA8_rA.text: Authentic, quick, good selection.  I've been coming here for years and always enjoy it.  Best with a group so you can sample more dishes.

128bX-s_Sy_SP2nr7OSYCA.text: Great Dim Sum!!! I recently moved to the Phoenix area, and was looking for good Dim Sum.  After going to a few different places, I came across C-Fu, and my search was over. Not only is there never a wait, but the service is second to none.  Usually stone cold servers at other Dim Sum places.  The carts come by right away, and the Dim Sum is always hot and fresh.  They have a larger selection than any other place I have tried.  I have been going every Sunday for the past 7 months, and make the 45 minute drive knowing I will get treated like family.  I highly recommend C-Fu to anyone looking for the best over all Dim Sum in the valley.

e0vWnjw175MuVSaAvcQIdg.text: We've been coming here regularly for years because the food is good (especially the dim sum and the live fish) and it's very family friendly.

5w0KjLNfDZtsg5jxCkGikQ.text: Well I used to LOVE this place. But it has been getting dirtier and dirtier and a few months ago it was on Dirty Dining. It is a shame as we used to go there at least once a month.

UWXeDu7UctZNkLwWqpA2Mw.text: Found this place by accident since we had intended to go to the Indian place next door which we sadly discovered had closed down. Since I had been looking for a Dim Sum place in Phoenix (similar to Chinatown in Chicago) we decided to give C-Fu a try. The food was "ok" but nothing to write home about (we came for lunch on the first visit). Dingy looking place, the food carts took forever to come around and food was  mostly cold.    The next visit was during dinner and we ordered the family meal from the menu that comes with appetizer, two entrees, etc. Although it was better than the lunch fare, it was no stand-out meal.    We decided to give lunch another try the other day and had a MISERABLE experience. Again, carts took forever, and with the exception of first order of steamed dumplings (shrimp and pork), everything was cold. To top it off, my 5 yr old son and I got terribly ill later that day. I spent the whole night hugging the toilet and was almost sent to the ER to get rehydrated. Needless to say, we are never going back to C-Fu! Oh, and they don't tell you that 15% tip is already added on to the check. Sneaky!

lOD94JlGvyurosRjD3qsuQ.text: Let's just say we ate here yesterday for lunch and I'm still running to the bathroom.  We went for the dim sum since a friend of mine highly recommended to place.  The atmosphere is nothing impressive, but hey, the food's what counts.  In this case it didn't.  Everything we tried was greasy and soaked in oil.  Yuck.  We loaded up on a few dishes, and I'm glad we did because after we did the carts were nowhere to be seen in our part.  They went around the side of the restaurant to the back tables, ignoring us.  We probably would have spent more money but they wouldn't serve us.  Meanwhile, the staff would keep coming up to us asking if we were done.  I mean this happened like 3 times in 15 minutes.  We kept saying no, but they wouldn't bring the cart by.  In fact, one of them even took my plate away.  Long story short, I'm not coming back.

gEw3iUy0c50QkrMdYokr4w.text: I'm slowing picking off members of my family and converting them to dim sum. Ah yes, domination by egg custard or, perhaps, bok choy. It serves as a solid culinary experience when I can't venture to Chinatown in San Fran for a fix. C-Fu offers a fantastic selection of barbeque pork buns (steamed is better, according to youngest bro), eggplant stuffed with shrimp (my fave) and spicy calamari. Consider it tapas, Chinese style.

Zwf9Sa1uz0R_agoy9_v5Sg.text: Dim sum is pretty bad. I have never tried such bad dim sum in my life before.  Service is not that good too.  Those who've never tried dim sum in their life before will say this place is good but actually it is NOT good at all.   There are 3 good dim sum places in Phoenix area: Golden Buddha, Great Wall, Phoenix Palace on Ray (not the one on Warner). China King is above average but it is not in my favorite list.

f1rTfiLVW5oofYlhTSEkYg.text: This is the only place that I know of that serves Dim Sum in the east valley. My family and I meet up here at least once a month to enjoy real authentic Chinese food. They never disappoint and they roll up with carts of food as soon as you sit down. You don't wait at all. I would highly recommend if you enjoy real Chinese food.

Q5YH9t6cyKAt5etAIpJqLA.text: We have been Dim Sum dinners at C Fu for decades.  The place is large and we can always get in.  Our guests enjoy the constant parade of carts and variety of dishes.  I have to act as the pace setter as there is a tendency to fill up quickly instead of moving along at a friendly relaxed time.  I have never really paid attention to the prices exept we are always suprised that such a large group eat for so little cost.   We have tried some of the others but keep comming back to C Fu.  Is sort of like family I guess.  Come and sit a spell...sip some tea and have a bite or two or ...

F-EzZxrKdq90UJVSDCaj8g.text: Dim Sum mmm mmm  good!  My wife and I had to pretty much roll out of there...we ate WAY too much!  The biggest problem was that you keep ordering more and more as the carts roll by.  We've been back a few times for Dim Sum and will be going back again!

L-RyP9gsSWXMv8eFsTWNRw.text: Coming from the Bay Area where there are millions of great Chinese restaurants, I have to say that C-Fu is pretty good. Who would have though in AZ? Dim sum is good. I love the cheese wontons.

PjIBuqbXI99v-6-598-YEg.text: C-Fu Gourmet has been wonderful.  They have so many options it can overwhelming, but they answer all your questions.  Every time I go there, I ask to make sure that there is no fish, shellfish, animal product in their sauces, and they are honest about it and offer vegetarian substitutions which is always nice.  A little bit on the pricier side but always worth it.  Their bird's nest dish (veggie style) is my absolute favorite.  It's a bowl made out of dried noodles with steamed vegetables and sauce inside.

pIcK4FnPnXCjmGCJAfn4Xg.text: 4 stars.  C-Fu is one of the first dim sum tea houses in the Valley and I've been going for years.  I'm a little surprised by some of the negative feedback given of C-Fu, but admittedly the place can seem a little rowdy, with the service sometimes being spotty, and the selections a little sparse (especially on weekdays).  But, on the whole, you're bound to find dim sum classics like pork siu mai, har gow, etc..., and on weekends the place is brimming with grill carts serving stuffed bell peppers, chinese broccoli (kai lan), and a soup vat is hauled around the dining hall with traditional "jook" (cantonese rice porridge).
